key_facts: Headhunters were born to fill specialized roles like chief executive or head of research.
Pre-internet recruitment relied on high street shops and paper CVs.
Recruitment agencies previously had only candidates who walked in seeking jobs.
Companies used Yellow Pages or Rolodexes to find recruiters before the internet.
Headhunters historically stole candidates from competitors.
LinkedIn enables access to any skill set for recruitment or headhunting.
Original headhunters were highly networked individuals with access to elite talent.
A headhunter must conduct face-to-face meetings with clients to understand needs.
Some headhunters are restricted to approaching candidates from the top 10 companies in a sector.
Headhunters provide industry insight into competitors as part of their service.
Cold calls are a common method for contacting potential candidates.
Emails can be sent to work addresses, which may be monitored.
Headhunting is primarily focused on permanent positions, not temporary ones.
Top neurosurgeons can be recruited by former hospital directors turned headhunters.
Executive search applies to roles with salaries above £80,000.
FTSE 100 and NASDAQ companies typically maintain specialist headhunters in their contacts.
key_opinions: The market has opened up greatly due to LinkedIn, leveling the playing field.
Anyone can now potentially contact CEOs of Google or Microsoft via LinkedIn.
Building relationships takes two to five years and involves trust-building.
Sending quick messages on LinkedIn is unlikely to engage high-caliber professionals.
Relationships are often built through events, dinners, and gifts.
Bribing is sometimes implied as a method to build connections.
High-volume, low-margin recruitment is personally preferred over executive search.
Headhunting is a dog-eat-dog environment requiring constant effort.
Candidates are more likely to engage with those having strong academic or sector experience.
Not everyone can successfully build relationships with top-tier professionals.
key_datapoints: Headhunters charge fees between £10,000 and millions per placement.
Fees make up about six percent of overall recruitment service spend.
Placements for top neurosurgeons can earn £50,000 to £100,000 per hire.
Multi-million pound placements have been reported.
Executive search targets roles with salaries above £80,000.
Starting salary for executive recruiters is around £20,000.
Commission earnings range from £10,000 to £30,000 in a good company.
Five years of experience in one sector is required to become a headhunter.
One or two introductions per year are typical for niche headhunters.
Candidates with 12 jobs in six years are less likely to engage with recruiters.
